body.p:
To His Excellency
The Govenor of Kentucky

Your Petitioners Thos O'Neal, Lance O'Neal John Merrill and George Harman, respectfully State that various endictments for gaming have been returned against them in the Jefferson Circuit Court, as follows; Some against Thos O'Neal alone, Some against Thos O'Neal & Lance O'Neal, Some against Thos O'Neal & John Merril and Some against George Harman. Some of the endictments charging gaming at "Faro" and others at "Rogue Ã¨t Noir" or "Red and Black"

Your petitioners confess to your Excellency that they did indulge in Said games; that it was at the Race Course in Jefferson County, & at Such places they have observed such things to have been hertofore permitted or prosecution not to have been had till now, hence they acted; and it is not for gaming Elsewhere that the Endictments have been returned.

They State to Your Excellency
that they are advised that the fine upon each Endictment is $500- & that they are wholly unable to pay the Same; whereupon they respectfully & Ernestly pray your Excellency to pardon them for the offences of their gaming, before any judgement Shall be rendered against them in the premesis. For after judgement, they are advised there would be an amount not in the power of the Executive to remit & which your petitioners would be unable to pay. They State that the gaming took place during the Race weeks & to return so many Endictments would be oppressive even if Your petitioners were able to pay, which they again assure your Excellency that they are not & therefore they respectfully pray pardon.

Thos. J. O'Neal
Lance.L. O'Neal
George Harmon
J J Merrell
To His Excellency the Governor of Kentucky:

I am personally acquainted with the young men presenting this petition for executive clemency They are charged with violating the law of Gaming and the facts seem to be that it was upon a public Race Course near the City of Louisville:

If I believed that the proceeding was taken against the petitioners to uphold the law in punishing the guilty and detering others from the commission of like offenses and thereby support the law and uphold public morals. I could not sign the petition: but when the prosecution appar to be, for any other purpose and in this case the great number of accusations seem not to be for such purpose: I therifore join in the prayer of the petitn

E S Craig
We are well acquainted with the Petitioners and hope Your Excellency will grant the prayer of the petition as we can see no good reason for making them an example
They are all poor men and totally unable to pay the fine- They have families & judgments against the petitioners would result in distress to their families.

W. G. Reasor
W R Ray
J H Harvey
Henry Dent
D. R. Haygood
